newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil govt to sell excess Petrobras shrs-minister.
newsitem.headline: Brazil govt to sell excess Petrobras shrs-minister.

text.p: The Brazilian government plans to sell excess shares it holds in state-run oil firm Petrobras with a current market value of 6.6 billion reais, Planning Minister Antonio Kandir said Thursday.
Kandir said no date for the sale has been set yet and the only decision so far was to transfer the equivalent of 22.3 percent of Petrobras' capital stock to the National Privatization Fund.
"We are heading in the direction of really only keeping 50 plus one percent of the ordinary shares of Petrobras," Kandir said after a meeting of the National Privatization Council (CND).
"So we will sell 31.7 percent of ordinary shares and 9.2 percent of preferred shares. When, we don't know," he added.
The Brazilian government currently holds 81.7 percent or ordinary shares and 9.2 percent of preferred shares.

Jose Pio Borges, privatization director of the National Development Bank (BNDES), said that the new Oil Law, signed into law last week, stipulated that the government need only control 50 percent plus one of ordinary shares.
"The government will be able to sell all its preferred shares," Borges said.

Kandir said the 22.3 percent of capital stock which the gvernment still holds in excess of a controlling stake was currently sitting in a Debt Retirement Fund (FAD) and was worth 6.6 billion reais at current market value.
After the shares were transferred from the fund to the National Privatization Fund, the council will hire consultants to advise on how best to sell the stock, he said.
